pageContext.title: 9 rising startups in Southeast Asia you need to look at
pageContext.content:
Which are the startups that are on the path to becoming the next big thing? In this regular post, we give you an overview of the companies that have raised money in the past week, as well as those that we think investors should look at. Want your startup featured on this list? Details below.

1. First Circle (Philippines)

Using its own credit assessment process, First Circle lends to SMEs, which are often ignored by banks because they’re perceived to be a greater risk than large established firms.

Amount raised: US$26 million
Round: Series A
Investors: Venturra Capital led the round, with Insignia Ventures Partners, Silverhorn Investment Advisors, and Tryb Group joining in.
Source: Tech in Asia

2. AI Grid Foundation (Singapore)

AI Grid Foundation aims to replace fossil fuels with renewable energy sources such as solar power. But rather than making use of traditional power plants, it will tap individual customers to generate, store, and distribute power in community microgrids.

Amount raised: US$20 million
Round: Undisclosed
Investors: OK Blockchain Capital, Krypital Group, Starwin Capital, Fenbushi Capital, LD Capital, Horman Capital, Collinstar Capital, Interblock Capital, JRR Crypto, Fly Fund, Qingzheng Capital, Decentrust Capital, Powerlink Labs, GVC.PE, and Ceyuan Digital Assets
Source: Tech in Asia

3. MobilityX (Singapore)

MobilityX is a Singapore-based “mobility-as-a-service” startup owned by the city-state’s largest transport operator, SMRT Corporation. MobilityX essentially allows transport operators to run their own multi-modal versions of transportation network apps like Grab or Uber.

Amount raised: Undisclosed
Round: Series A
Investors: Toyota Tsusho led the round
Source: Tech in Asia

4. Xjera Labs (Singapore)

Xjera Labs is working on automated surveillance with Changi Airport as a customer. It uses a mix of video and audio analytics to detect anomalies and reduce false positives.

Amount raised: Undisclosed
Round: Grant
Investors: The Infocomm Media Development Authority, and the Ministry of Home Affairs
Source: Tech in Asia

5. UberGard (Singapore)

UberGard is improving and even replacing the management of physical keys in premises. It’s testing a system that enables building access to a person through automated key retrieval, key-press access, iris scans, and facial recognition.

Amount raised: Undisclosed
Round: Grant
Investors: The Infocomm Media Development Authority, and the Ministry of Home Affairs
Source: Tech in Asia

6. Arkemis (Singapore)

Arkemis will pilot a security command center at various condominiums. The new center aims to make security management more efficient.

Amount raised: Undisclosed
Round: Grant
Investors: The Infocomm Media Development Authority, and the Ministry of Home Affairs
Source: Tech in Asia

7. Chate Sat (Myanmar)

Chate Sat is a freelancer platform. It has 14,000 freelancers on its website, covering web and mobile development, designers, marketers, and more.

Amount raised: Six-figure US dollars
Round: Bridge
Investors: Singapore angel investors Willy Ballmann and Keizo Fujitake
Source: DealStreetAsia

8. XRVision (Singapore)

XRVision is a facial recognition and video analytics startup focusing on security.

Amount raised: Unknown
Round: Unknown
Investors: Boundary Holding
Source: DealStreetAsia

9. Analisa (Indonesia)

Analisa is an Instagram analytics service that lets you analyze the engagement of various Instagram accounts or hashtags. Its targets marketers, agencies, and social media influencers as its customers. Users must pay a subscription fee to access advanced analytics.

Is your startup headquartered in Southeast Asia? Want your startup to be featured in future editions of this list? Here are the steps:

  1. Check if your startup’s profile already exists on Tech in Asia through our company search feature.
  2. Go to the create a company profile page. You’ll need an account to be able to do so. Fill out the name of your company. If your company profile is already in our database, you have the option of claiming it and modifying the details. If your company profile doesn’t exist, please create one.
  3. Fill out this form with your startup’s details. We’ll review it when we make a new list.

Note that we have to be selective in the startups that we pick. That is because we generally want startups that might interest investors or venture capitalists. The Google form should give you an idea of what we’re looking out for. Good luck!

See previous rising startup lists here.

seo.title: 9 rising startups in Southeast Asia you need to look at
seo.description: Here are the startups that are on the path to becoming the next big thing?
